title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
text:
Associated with Tickle College of Engineering at the University of Tennessee
June 2025 - July 2025
This page details my work as an Undergraduate Researcher under Dr. Garrett Rose, focusing on low-temperature memory design for quantum and neuromorphic computing applications. The project involved two main components: experimental evaluation of memristor failure at cryogenic temperatures and the design of a custom PCB (“Octopus PCB”).

title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
section: RESET-Failure Evaluation of HfO₂-Based Memristors at Cryogenic Temperatures
text:
RESET-Failure Evaluation of HfO₂-Based Memristors at Cryogenic Temperatures
Skills: Python (Programming Language) · C++ · Keysight B1500A Semiconductor Tester · Data Analysis

This study investigates RESET failure in HfO₂-based memristors at cryogenic temperatures. RESET failure is defined as a destructive event in which the device becomes permanently stuck at a fixed resistance.
Using a B1500A Semiconductor Device Analyzer and a FormFactor PMC200 cryogenic probe station, the applied RESET voltage was progressively lowered at 70 K until failure occurred.
Download Technical Report (PDF)

title: Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
text:
Octopus PCB
Skills: Printed Circuit Board (PCB) Design · 3D Design · PCB Design
The main function of the PCB is to allow the user to connect two 25 Position D-Sub Male Cable to then be connected to Analog Input Pixie 6365 or a Analog Output Pixie 6738.






Final PCB on Mounting Board







Outline of PCB











3D Rendering of PCB





Download Schematic (PDF)
The input from the 25 D-Sub cable goes through a 100 ohm resistor which can be bypassed with a switch. It then enters into the analog input cable. There is a second switch which then connects it to the analog output cable. The analog output can be run with the pin still connected to the analog input at the same time. The analog input can not be run while connected to the analog output. In addition each of the pins can be accessed through a RF Connector or through test pads located before the analog output side.

title: Research & Projects
text: This page showcases my hands-on research and engineering project experience, highlighting my ability to apply theoretical knowledge to practical challenges.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Academic Research

Cryogenic Characterization of HfO2 Memristors
Undergraduate Researcher | University of Tennessee Knoxville (Summer 2025)


RESET-Failure Evaluation: Investigated failure mechanisms in HfO2-based memristors at 77K using a cryogenic probe station and semiconductor analyzer.
Octopus PCB: Designed a custom PCB for connecting D-Sub cables to Analog Input/Output Pixies, enabling flexible testing configurations.

A Tribological Study of The Optimization of Pizza Making
STLE Atlanta Student Poster Session (June 2025)


Investigated the optimum ratio of flour to dough to minimize friction and prevent burning during pizza making.
Presented findings at the Annual 2025 STLE Meeting.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Clinic Projects

Regenerative Load for HITL Test System
Senior Clinic Project | Exolambda (Current) * Collaborating with a team to design and build a regenerative load for a Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) test system, requiring a minimum of three variable loads at 48 V and 10 A capacity. * Heavily involved in the physical building and testing of regenerative aspects, utilizing buck and boost converters and grid-tie inverters to refine the overall architecture. * Coordinated with team members on variable load development, ensuring interface compatibility (connectors, test points). * Developed two distinct architecture setups: one feeding power back to AC mains via a grid-tie inverter, and another generating DC voltage back to the PSU. * Expanded systems-level design capabilities in an open-ended project environment.


Air Quality Sensor Communication Hardware Upgrade
Junior Clinic Project | UC Berkeley - Civil & Environmental Engineering (Advisor: Chelsea Preble) * Updated communication hardware for an existing air sensor system used to measure air quality around industrial areas of Oakland. * Researched and identified suitable wireless communication protocols and hardware options to transmit sensor data to a web server. * Considered numerous outside factors, including location constraints, community WiFi access, signal strength in industrial areas, and LoRaWAN gateway availability. * Navigated significant system limitations imposed by battery efficiency, which constrained sampling and data transmission rates, impacting overall system operational life. * Developed a “large system thinking” mindset, identifying factors beyond traditional electrical engineering to create a functional product for public good.

title: Research & Projects
text:
Coursework & Personal Projects

Analog Operational Amplifier Design
Coursework: Analog Circuit Design (ENGR151) * Designed and physically constructed a fully operational amplifier from scratch using BJTs. * Integrated complex subcircuits: current mirror, level shift, Class AB output stage, and common emitter with degeneration.


Microprocessor Systems Control & Integration
Coursework: Electronic and Microprocessor Systems (ENGR155) * Programmed an STM32L432KC Microcontroller to generate Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) waves for a speaker and interpret pulses from a motor encoder using interrupts. * Integrated systems to read temperature from a DS1722 sensor and display results on an ESP8266 Webserver.


Digital Audio Effects Guitar Pedals
Final Project: Electronic and Microprocessor Systems (ENGR155) (Ongoing) * Developing guitar pedals to add audio effects (degradation chorus, reverb) using an external ADC, FPGA, and STM32 MCU in tandem.

title: A Tribological Study of The Optimization of Pizza Making
text:
Presented at the Annual 2025 STLE Meeting
June 2025

Pizza makers have consistently faced a challenge when dusting pizza dough with flour. Too much flour and the pizza burns in the oven, not enough and the dough does not slide off the peel. To find the answer to this dilemma varying amounts of flour were added to pizza dough and the effect on the dough’s ability to slide on a surface effectively was examined. Through this, an optimum ratio of semolina flour to pizza dough was determined in order to give pizza makers everywhere a reliable measurement of flour they could use to overcome friction without inducing burning.
Download Student Poster (PDF)

title: Kanoa Parker
text:
I am a final year Electrical Engineering undergraduate at Harvey Mudd College, passionate about the power efficiency of Integrated Circuits and the development of novel device architectures. I am actively pursuing PhD opportunities, to contribute to cutting-edge research in signal processing and control theory.
My core motivation stems from the critical energy gap facing modern computing, from power-intensive AI to data center demands. I believe that optimizing the power efficiency of Integrated Circuits is a highly effective approach to addressing this challenge. My academic and research experiences have equipped me with a strong foundation in practical application and component-level development, fostering a systems-level thinking mindset to create functional and impactful products.
My goal is to develop reliable and power-efficient solutions that can scale sustainably, especially as AI and intelligent interfaces become more pervasive. I am particularly interested in working with faculty focused on power and energy.




Integrated Circuit Power Efficiency: Novel device architectures, resistive memory, low-temperature memory design.
Signal Processing & Control Systems: Embedded control, digital signal processing, system integration for real-world applications.
Microelectronics: Memristors, cryogenic testing, semiconductor device analysis.
System-Level Design: Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) systems, power electronics (buck/boost converters, grid tie inverters).
